title: Steall Falls Walk Route

images.title: Malcolm Manners from Lakeland FL, USA [CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0)]
images.caption: A group of walkers make their way along the footpath to the falls in the autumn of 2015. In popular culture the falls are known as the site of the Harry Potter contest to get the golden egg from a dragon, in Goblet of Fire.

images.title: Richard Laybourne / Cairn above Eas an Tuill
images.caption: Cairn above Eas an Tuill Slightly off the standard track, a smaller path wends its way above the gorge. It's not on the map, but gets a mention in Pathfinder Guide for Fort William and Glen Coe and makes a nice detour on the return from the Steall Falls.

images.title: Ian Stewart / Steall Falls
images.caption: Close up view of the falls in June 2009

images.title: Andrew Wood / Steall Rope Bridge
images.caption: Steall Rope Bridge. Not for the faint hearted a novel river crossing at Steall.

images.title: Steve  F [CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)]
images.caption: Cross if you dare! The Steall wire rope bridge.

description: Visit the second highest waterfall in Scotland on this short walk in Glen Nevis. Steall waterfall is a spectacular sight dropping 120 metres (390 ft) down a rockface. The walk begins at the car park near the falls and follows a good footpath through the lovely Nevis Gorge. You'll pass along the River Nevis, through woodland and meadows with wonderful views of the surrounding mountains. It's a stunningly beautiful place and one of the most popular walks in the area. Highlights on the route include a popular wire rope bridge pictured below and featured in the video. The precarious bridge is a fun way of crossing the Water of Nevis but is not for the faint hearted!
